User:Generate the lists of enumerations, classes and attributes from a given <Description>.
#Description 
A smart home automation system (SHAS) offers various users to automatically manage smart home automation tasks. A smart home (located at a physical address) consists of several rooms, each of which may contain sensor devices and actuator (controller) devices of different types (e.g. temperature sensor, movement sensor, light controller, lock controller). Each sensor and actuator have a unique device identifier. Once a new sensor or actuator is activated or deactivated, SHAS will recognize the change and update its infrastructure map.
When SHAS is operational, a sensor device periodically provides sensor readings (recording the measured value and the timestamp). Similarly, a predefined set of control commands (e.g. lockDoor, turnOnHeating) can be sent to the actuator devices with the timestamp and the status of the command (e.g. requested, completed, failed, etc.). All sensor readings and control commands for a smart home are recorded by SHAS in an activity log.
Relevant alerts in a smart home can be set up and managed by its owner by setting up automation rules. An automation rule has a precondition and an action. The precondition is a Boolean expression constructed from relational terms connected by basic Boolean operators (AND, OR, NOT). Atomic relational terms may refer to rooms, sensors, actuators, sensor readings and control commands. The action is a sequence of control commands. For example, a sample rule could specify:
when actualTemperature by Device #1244 in Living Room < 18 and window is closed 
then turnOnHeating in Living Room
Automation rules can be created, edited, activated and deactivated by owners. Only deactivated rules can be edited. Rules can also depend on or conflict with other rules, thus a complex rule hierarchy can be designed. SHAS records whenever an active rule was triggered using a timestamp.


AI:## Enumerations:
1. DeviceType
   - TEMPERATURE_SENSOR
   - MOVEMENT_SENSOR
   - LIGHT_CONTROLLER
   - LOCK_CONTROLLER

2. CommandStatus
   - REQUESTED
   - COMPLETED
   - FAILED

## Classes:
1. SmartHome
   - physicalAddress: String
   - rooms: List<Room>

2. Room
   - roomId: String
   - sensors: List<Sensor>
   - actuators: List<Actuator>

3. Sensor
   - deviceId: String
   - deviceType: DeviceType
   - readings: List<SensorReading>

4. Actuator
   - deviceId: String
   - deviceType: DeviceType
   - commands: List<ControlCommand>

5. SensorReading
   - measuredValue: Double
   - timestamp: Date

6. ControlCommand
   - command: String
   - timestamp: Date
   - status: CommandStatus

7. ActivityLog
   - sensorReadings: List<SensorReading>
   - controlCommands: List<ControlCommand>

8. AutomationRule
   - precondition: String
   - action: List<String>
   - isActive: Boolean
   - dependencies: List<AutomationRule>
   - conflicts: List<AutomationRule>
   - lastTriggeredTimestamp: Date

## Attributes:
- SmartHome
  - physicalAddress

- Room
  - roomId

- Sensor
  - deviceId
  - deviceType

- Actuator
  - deviceId
  - deviceType

- SensorReading
  - measuredValue
  - timestamp

- ControlCommand
  - command
  - timestamp
  - status

- AutomationRule
  - precondition
  - action
  - isActive
  - lastTriggeredTimestamp

AI:Enumerations:
1. DeviceType(TEMPERATURE_SENSOR, MOVEMENT_SENSOR, LIGHT_CONTROLLER, LOCK_CONTROLLER): Represents the different types of sensor and actuator devices in a smart home.
2. CommandStatus(REQUESTED, COMPLETED, FAILED): Represents the status of a control command sent to an actuator device.

Classes:
1. SmartHome(physicalAddress: String, rooms: List<Room>): Represents a smart home with a physical address and a list of rooms.
2. Room(roomId: String, sensors: List<Sensor>, actuators: List<Actuator): Represents a room within a smart home containing sensor and actuator devices.
3. Sensor(deviceId: String, deviceType: DeviceType, readings: List<SensorReading): Represents a sensor device with a unique identifier, device type, and sensor readings.
4. Actuator(deviceId: String, deviceType: DeviceType, commands: List<ControlCommand): Represents an actuator device with a unique identifier, device type, and control commands.
5. SensorReading(measuredValue: Double, timestamp: Date): Represents a sensor reading with a measured value and timestamp.
6. ControlCommand(command: String, timestamp: Date, status: CommandStatus): Represents a control command with a command string, timestamp, and status.
7. ActivityLog(sensorReadings: List<SensorReading>, controlCommands: List<ControlCommand): Represents an activity log recording sensor readings and control commands.
8. AutomationRule(precondition: String, action: List<String>, isActive: Boolean, dependencies: List<AutomationRule>, conflicts: List<AutomationRule>, lastTriggeredTimestamp: Date): Represents an automation rule with a precondition, action, activation status, dependencies, conflicts, and last triggered timestamp.

User:Generate the lists of enumerations, classes and attributes from a given <Description>.
#Description 
A smart home automation system (SHAS) offers various users to automatically manage smart home automation tasks. A smart home (located at a physical address) consists of several rooms, each of which may contain sensor devices and actuator (controller) devices of different types (e.g. temperature sensor, movement sensor, light controller, lock controller). Each sensor and actuator have a unique device identifier. Once a new sensor or actuator is activated or deactivated, SHAS will recognize the change and update its infrastructure map.
When SHAS is operational, a sensor device periodically provides sensor readings (recording the measured value and the timestamp). Similarly, a predefined set of control commands (e.g. lockDoor, turnOnHeating) can be sent to the actuator devices with the timestamp and the status of the command (e.g. requested, completed, failed, etc.). All sensor readings and control commands for a smart home are recorded by SHAS in an activity log.
Relevant alerts in a smart home can be set up and managed by its owner by setting up automation rules. An automation rule has a precondition and an action. The precondition is a Boolean expression constructed from relational terms connected by basic Boolean operators (AND, OR, NOT). Atomic relational terms may refer to rooms, sensors, actuators, sensor readings and control commands. The action is a sequence of control commands. For example, a sample rule could specify:
when actualTemperature by Device #1244 in Living Room < 18 and window is closed 
then turnOnHeating in Living Room
Automation rules can be created, edited, activated and deactivated by owners. Only deactivated rules can be edited. Rules can also depend on or conflict with other rules, thus a complex rule hierarchy can be designed. SHAS records whenever an active rule was triggered using a timestamp.

AI:### Enumerations:
1. DeviceType (TemperatureSensor, MovementSensor, LightController, LockController): Represents different types of sensor and actuator devices for a smart home automation system.
2. CommandStatus (Requested, Completed, Failed): Defines the status of control commands sent to actuator devices.

### Classes:
1. SmartHome (physicalAddress: String, rooms: List<Room>): Represents a smart home with a physical address and rooms containing sensor and actuator devices.
2. Room (sensors: List<SensorDevice>, actuators: List<ActuatorDevice>): Represents a room in a smart home with sensor and actuator devices.
3. SensorDevice (deviceId: String, sensorReadings: List<SensorReading>): Represents a sensor device with a unique identifier and sensor readings.
4. ActuatorDevice (deviceId: String, controlCommands: List<ControlCommand>): Represents an actuator device with a unique identifier and control commands.
5. SensorReading (measuredValue: Double, timestamp: Date): Represents a sensor reading with a measured value and timestamp.
6. ControlCommand (command: String, timestamp: Date, status: CommandStatus): Represents a control command with a command string, timestamp, and status.
7. ActivityLog (sensorReadings: List<SensorReading>, controlCommands: List<ControlCommand>): Represents the activity log recording sensor readings and control commands.
8. AutomationRule (precondition: String, action: List<String>, isActive: Boolean, isEditable: Boolean, dependencyRules: List<AutomationRule>, conflictingRules: List<AutomationRule): Represents an automation rule with a precondition, action, and rule management attributes.

AI:Enumerations:
1. DeviceType(TEMPERATURE_SENSOR, MOVEMENT_SENSOR, LIGHT_CONTROLLER, LOCK_CONTROLLER): Represents the types of sensor and actuator devices in a smart home automation system.
2. CommandStatus(REQUESTED, COMPLETED, FAILED): Represents the status of control commands sent to actuator devices.

Classes:
1. SmartHome(address: String, rooms: List<Room>): Represents a smart home with its address and rooms containing sensor and actuator devices.
2. Room(sensors: List<SensorDevice>, actuators: List<ActuatorDevice): Represents a room in a smart home with sensor and actuator devices.
3. SensorDevice(deviceId: String, readings: List<SensorReading): Represents a sensor device with a unique identifier and sensor readings.
4. ActuatorDevice(deviceId: String, commands: List<ControlCommand): Represents an actuator device with a unique identifier and control commands.
5. SensorReading(value: double, timestamp: Date): Represents a sensor reading with a measured value and timestamp.
6. ControlCommand(commandType: String, timestamp: Date, status: CommandStatus): Represents a control command with type, timestamp, and status.
7. ActivityLog(sensorReadings: List<SensorReading>, controlCommands: List<ControlCommand): Represents the log of sensor readings and control commands in a smart home.
8. AutomationRule(precondition: String, action: List<ControlCommand>, active: boolean): Represents an automation rule with a precondition, action, and activation status.
9. RuleHierarchy(dependentRules: List<AutomationRule>, conflictingRules: List<AutomationRule): Represents the hierarchy of automation rules with dependent and conflicting rules.
10. Alert(description: String, triggeredTimestamp: Date): Represents an alert with a description and triggered timestamp.

1. DeviceType {temperature sensor, movement sensor, light controller, lock controller}
2. CommandStatus {requested, completed, failed}

Classes:
1. SmartHomeAutomationSystem
Attributes:

2. SmartHome
Attributes:
- address: String
- rooms: List<Room>

- sensors: List<SensorDevice>

- controlCommands: List<ControlCommand>

AI:Enumerations:
1. DeviceType {temperature sensor, movement sensor, light controller, lock controller}: Represents the different types of sensor and actuator devices that can be present in a smart home system.
2. CommandStatus {requested, completed, failed}: Represents the status of control commands sent to actuator devices in the smart home system.

Classes:
1. SmartHomeAutomationSystem(address: String): Represents the main system managing smart home automation tasks with a physical address.
2. SmartHome(address: String, rooms: List<Room>): Represents a smart home located at a physical address with multiple rooms containing sensor and actuator devices.
3. Room(roomNumber: int, sensors: List<SensorDevice>, actuators: List<ActuatorDevice): Represents a room within a smart home, equipped with sensor and actuator devices.
4. SensorDevice(deviceId: int, readings: List<SensorReading): Represents a sensor device with a unique identifier and sensor readings.
5. ActuatorDevice(deviceId: int, commands: List<ControlCommand): Represents an actuator device with a unique identifier and control commands.
6. SensorReading(value: double, timestamp: DateTime): Represents a sensor reading recording the measured value and timestamp.
7. ControlCommand(command: String, timestamp: DateTime, status: CommandStatus): Represents a control command sent to actuator devices with timestamp and status.
8. ActivityLog(smartHome: SmartHome, sensorReadings: List<SensorReading>, controlCommands: List<ControlCommand): Represents the activity log recording sensor readings and control commands for a smart home.
9. AutomationRule(precondition: String, action: List<ControlCommand>, isActive: boolean, isEditable: boolean, dependentRules: List<AutomationRule>, conflictingRules: List<AutomationRule): Represents an automation rule with a precondition and action, which can be activated, edited, and have dependencies or conflicts with other rules.
10. Alert(rule: AutomationRule, timestamp: DateTime): Represents a relevant alert set up in a smart home triggered by an active rule with a timestamp.

### Classes:
1. SmartHome(address: String, rooms: List<Room>, infrastructureMap: Map<Device, DeviceType): Represents a smart home with its address, rooms, and infrastructure mapping of devices.
2. Room(name: String, sensors: List<SensorDevice>, actuators: List<ActuatorDevice): Represents a room in a smart home containing sensor and actuator devices.

User:Generate the lists of enumerations, classes and attributes from a given <Description>.
#Description 
A smart home automation system (SHAS) offers various users to automatically manage smart home automation tasks. A smart home (located at a physical address) consists of several rooms, each of which may contain sensor devices and actuator (controller) devices of different types (e.g. temperature sensor, movement sensor, light controller, lock controller). Each sensor and actuator have a unique device identifier. Once a new sensor or actuator is activated or deactivated, SHAS will recognize the change and update its infrastructure map.
When SHAS is operational, a sensor device periodically provides sensor readings (recording the measured value and the timestamp). Similarly, a predefined set of control commands (e.g. lockDoor, turnOnHeating) can be sent to the actuator devices with the timestamp and the status of the command (e.g. requested, completed, failed, etc.). All sensor readings and control commands for a smart home are recorded by SHAS in an activity log.
Relevant alerts in a smart home can be set up and managed by its owner by setting up automation rules. An automation rule has a precondition and an action. The precondition is a Boolean expression constructed from relational terms connected by basic Boolean operators (AND, OR, NOT). Atomic relational terms may refer to rooms, sensors, actuators, sensor readings and control commands. The action is a sequence of control commands. For example, a sample rule could specify:
when actualTemperature by Device #1244 in Living Room < 18 and window is closed 
then turnOnHeating in Living Room
Automation rules can be created, edited, activated and deactivated by owners. Only deactivated rules can be edited. Rules can also depend on or conflict with other rules, thus a complex rule hierarchy can be designed. SHAS records whenever an active rule was triggered using a timestamp.

### Classes:
1. SmartHome (physicalAddress: String, rooms: List<Room): Represents a smart home with a physical address and a list of rooms containing sensor and actuator devices.

7. ActivityLog (sensorReadings: List<SensorReading>, controlCommands: List<ControlCommand): Represents an activity log recording sensor readings and control commands in a smart home.

8. AutomationRule (precondition: String, action: List<ControlCommand>, isActive: Boolean): Represents an automation rule with a precondition, action, and activation status.

9. RuleTriggerLog (ruleId: String, timestamp: Date): Represents a log entry recording when an automation rule was triggered.
